Review: collective action, philosophy and law
Mattias Gunnemyr
Department of Philosophy, Linguistics and Theory of Science, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden
ABSTRACT

The anthology Collective Action, Philosophy and Law brings together two key strands of philosophical inquiry: social ontology and jurisprudence. Most of the papers use collective agency as a starting point to get a better grasp on collective entities and activities in the legal domain, but others reverse the approach and use legal examples to refine theories of collective agency. The introduction provides a comprehensive overview of the literature on collective agency, emphasizing issues in jurisprudence and legal practices where collective agency plays a central role. It also offers a detailed overview of the anthology's structure and contents. With thirteen papers organized into four parts, the anthology covers a broad spectrum of topics. While each paper deserves in-depth exploration, this review will provide a brief summary of all the papers, followed by concise discussions of the contributions of Sara Rachel Chant and Bill Wringe.
ARTICLE HISTORY
Received 21 December 2023
Accepted 16 February 2024
KEYWORDS
Collective action; collective agents; social ontology; jurisprudence; review

The anthology *Collective Action*, Philosophy and Law unites two significant threads of philosophical examination: social ontology and jurisprudence. While most of the papers take accounts of collective agency as a point of departure to better understand collective entities and activities in the legal domain, some go in the opposite direction, using examples from the law to elaborate theories of collective agency.

The introduction first gives an excellent overview of the scholarly discussion on collective agency. It then highlights jurisprudence and legal practice issues where social ontology and joint agency are pivotal. It also gives a detailed overview of the different parts and papers of the anthology, more detailed than I can provide here. The anthology features thirteen papers spanning over four parts. While most papers merit a thorough discussion, I limit myself to giving a concise overview of the papers and briefly discussing two personal favorites.
PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCHOLOGY
ROUTED
Routledge
Taylor & Francis Group
CONTACT Mattias Gunnemyr
\times
mattias.gunnemyr@gu.se
Â© 2024 The Author(s). Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.

The terms on which this article has been published allow the posting of the Accepted Manuscript in a repository by the author(s) or with their consent.
Part I: the nature of law and legislative intention

The first part of the anthology concerns the nature of law and its connection to legislative intentions. Many understandings of law â such as Hart's (1961) conception of law as a social convention, Dworkin's (1986) natural-law-inspired conception, and the political conception â struggle to explain the existence of legal disputes. As a broadly Hartian alternative, Kevin Toh argues in âCollectivity and Lawâ that we should understand legal judgments as directed toward initiating and sustaining a collective acceptance of norms, building on Bratman's (1993) planning theory of shared agency.

Legal officials frequently assert that they interpret statutes in light of the legislative intention behind them. However, Damiano Canale argues in "Legislative Intent, Collective Intentionality and Fictionalism" that plausible accounts of collective intentionality do not support the claim that legislatures have such intentions. Still, he continues, courts and others may proceed fictionally and act as if there were legislative intentions, at least if these intentions cohere with precedents and other related legal materials.

Brian Flanagan's contribution also concerns legal intentions. He argues that legal positivists should identify texts' legal meanings with their historically intended meanings rather than, for instance, official practice, as Shapiro's planning theory (Shapiro, 2011) does. Doing so provides the best explanation for legal disagreement, and hence, they can escape Dworkin's influential objection that legal positivists cannot explain such disputes. In contrast to Canele, Flanagan argues that plausible accounts of collective intentionality can account for such intentions.

Like Flanagan's chapter, the following two papers concern Shapiro's planning theory of law (one of these papers belongs to Part II). It is widely held that Shapiro's (2011) planning theory provides legal positivism with a comparative advantage over anti-positivism, where legal positivism is the idea that law is wholly socially constructed and rooted in convention, while legal anti-positivism claims there is a moral dimension to law. In "The two lives of law's moral aim", Dimitrios Kyritsis questions that views like Shapiro's lack a moral dimension, arguing that moral considerations necessarily structure legal officials' joint activities.
Part II: practical reasoning and duties

The second part of the anthology is about practical reasoning and duties in relation to the law. In the first paper in this part, Natalie Gold presents an alternative to Shapiro's (2011) approach using an account of team reasoning. She argues that her model, unlike Shapiro's, can make sense of shared agency in massively large unstructured groups, partly because it lacks a common knowledge
PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCHOLOGY

requirement on shared agency. Her account also eliminates the need for mutual responsiveness among group members, addressing Dworkin's disagreement-based argument against the concept of law as a joint activity.

The second paper of this part also concerns team reasoning. Here, Caroline T. Arruda considers situations where a group has a collective moral obligation and where the individuals in the group care about the reasons for which others participate in discharging this obligation. In such cases, whether others participate for the right reasons matters for how the individual group member should deliberate. Arruda argues that current accounts of team reasoning (Gold & Sugden, 2007; Petersson, 2017) and collective agency (List & Pettit, 2011) cannot explain this phenomenon. Toward the end, she considers the consequences of this result for Hart's (1961) view that we must be invested in the law for it to impose binding obligations upon us.

Next, Abraham Sesshu Roth argues that we cannot explain directed duties in terms of relational wrongdoing, accountability, or normative power. Instead, he suggests that such duties originate in shared agency. However, this idea is challenged by the existence of directed legal duties in tort law. You have a directed duty not to assault strangers, even though this is not a case of joint agency. Further, he suggests that the directed duties in tort law might be explained as duties to reconcile, which is a joint project.
Part III: causality, blameworthiness and responsibility

Part III concerns relations between causality, blameworthiness, and responsibility. In the first contribution of this part, Sara Rachel Chant warns that we should not use our theories of individual moral agency, responsibility, and rights as a template for understanding the agency, responsibility, and rights of collectives. Notably, she argues, we should not necessarily grant collective agents (such as corporations) all the rights individual citizens have (such as the freedom of speech).

Sara Bernstein argues convincingly in her contribution that deviant causal chains demonstrate that the legal distinction between attempts and completed crimes is unsatisfactory and that mens rea, actus reus, plus actual causation are not sufficient for legal responsibility, in contrast to what is commonly supposed.

Nicholas Almendares criticizes causal accounts of complicity, focusing on John Gardner's (2007) account and the foreseeability doctrine in law. The main idea is that such accounts unavoidably count people who are not morally responsible as accomplices. As an alternative, Almendares suggests that we should understand complicity in terms of joint intentions.
M.GUNNEMYR
Part IV: citizens, states and institutions

Bill Wringe's "Expressive Theories of Punishment" opens the fourth and final part of the anthology, which explores relevant matters within the legal-philosophical debate that have received comparatively less attention, with a focus on the relationship between governments, states, and their citizens. Building on Grice's (1957) account of meaning, Wringe argues that we should not understand expressive accounts of legal punishment (e.g., Duff's, 2001, account) as claiming that the state communicates messages of reprobation to the offender, but rather to society as a whole.

Next, building on Dworkin (1986) and Gardner (2002), Maggie O'Brien makes the case that national communities are collective agents and contends that a charter or bill of rights strengthens the bonds between the community members, making it a better moral agent.

In the part's concluding paper, which is also the last one in the anthology, Carla Bagnoli considers forms of collective agency peripheral to the mainstream discussion. She contends that central accounts of joint agency like Bratman's (2014) and Gilbert's (2014) involve that members wholeheartedly endorse or fully commit to the shared plan, and thus, that alienation (i.e., a form of half-hearted or unreflected agency) is a mark of defective collective agency. She then argues that these accounts fail to capture some everyday cases of collective agency where alienation is frequent and where alienation might even facilitate collective agency.
In what remains of this review, I will consider two of the contributions in more detail.
Sara Rachel Chant on corporate rights and non-distributive group responsibility

Can only collective agents bear (non-distributive) responsibility? Do collective agents have the same rights and privileges as individual agents? Sara Rachel Chant argues that such questions distract from more important ones. What matters for whether a corporation, political association, etc., can bear responsibility or have rights is not whether it belongs to the ontological category of being an agent but the structure and dynamics of the group.

As a case in point, she considers the Supreme Court's infamous decision in *Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission*, which grants corporations free speech rights and thereby revoked the prohibition for corporations to express advocacy for political parties within 30 days of an election. As motivation for his concurrence, Judge Anthony Scalia argues that there is no relevant difference between political associations and business corporations. When any such organization expresses an opinion, it speaks for its members. They have associated with a common cause, giving a leader the
PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCHOLOGY
right to speak on their behalf. The majority opinion of the court cites a similar argument.

Chant disagrees. There is a significant difference. A political party expresses the opinions of its members (or comes close to doing so). Therefore, restricting the free speech of political parties amounts to denying its members the right to free speech. However, due to the structure and dynamics of the group, a powerful corporation does not typically express the opinions of its rank-and-file workers, but rather the views of a few top managers. So, restricting the free speech of corporations does not amount to denying its members the right to free speech. This shows that the structure and dynamics of the group matter for whether we should grant it free speech privileges and, likewise, that it is unimportant whether the group constitutes an agent or not.

In support of the idea that it is the structure and dynamics of a group that decides whether a group can bear non-distributive responsibility or have rights, Chant considers the following case, here presented in abridged form:

Hollywood Standoff: Mr. Good, Mr. Bad and Mr. Ugly are each holding a gun to the head of the next. Everyone knows that the first to shoot will surely be shot. Nearby, a child is suffering from severe dehydration. The men see this, and that the child could easily be saved if each were to lower the guns and give the child the last few sips of water from their flasks. Moreover, everyone believes that if anyone were to begin to lower his weapon, chaos could ensue, and everyone could get shot. However, they also see that it is possible that chaos would not ensue. If any man had begun to lower his gun, the other would have followed suit, and the child would have been saved. Nevertheless, the men maintain the standoff, and the child dies.

Here, Chant argues that the men are collectively, non-distributively, morally responsible for the death of the child. While each man has an excuse from individual - distributive - moral responsibility, the group lacks a similar excuse from non-distributive moral responsibility. Each man has an excuse since he faces a severe risk of being killed if he lowers his gun, and such threats typically absolve us from responsibility. However, Chant argues, nothing absolves the group from responsibility. The example shows that it can save the child but fails to do so. Moreover, if someone is threatened into doing something awful, the moral responsibility for the act typically falls on the source of the threat. In this case, the group is the source of the threat, meaning we should place "moral responsibility squarely on the group as a whole" (184). So, while none of the three men is morally responsible for the death of the child, the group of them is.

If correct, this is an important result (see also Chant, 2015). Since the group does not constitute a collective agent â for instance, it lacks a formal decision procedure (List & Pettit, 2011) â we have a case where a group bears collective, non-distributive, responsibility while not being a collective agent. Collective agency and collective
M.GUNNEMYR

responsibility can come apart, something that supports the idea that collective agency and collective rights also might come apart, as in Citizens United. In both cases, the structure and dynamics of the group matter, not whether it constitutes an agent.<sup>1</sup>

On a critical note, we can agree with Chant's argument concerning Citizens United that collective agency does not entail having certain moral rights and still challenge her idea that non-agential groups might have rights or be (non-distributively) morally responsible.

First, it seems Chant is correct in claiming that the group in *Hollywood Standoff* could save the child but fails to do so. Still, contrary to what she says, the group seems to have an excuse. Just like each individual truthfully can say that while there is a possibility that he would survive and be able to save the child if he lowered his gun, the threat of getting killed absolves him from responsibility, the group of them can truthfully say that while there is a possibility that they would survive and be able to save the child if they lowered their guns, the threat of getting killed absolves them from responsibility.

Second, as Chant claims, it is true that when someone is threatened into doing something awful, the moral responsibility for the act typically falls on the source of the threat. However, in this case, it is unclear why the group would be the source of the threat. Is it not rather that Mr Good is the source of the threat to Mr Bad, Mr Bad is the source of the threat to Mr Ugly, and Mr Ugly is the source of the threat to Mr Good? Chant argues that they are not individually morally responsible since "each of them is a threat only because they are themselves under threat" (182). This might be true. But this should not make us think that the threat comes from somewhere else (e.g., from the group), but rather that Mr Good is excused from being morally responsible for threatening Mr. Bad, and that Mr Bad and Mr Ugly likewise are excused. If this is correct, Chant's second argument for thinking that moral responsibility falls squarely on the group also misfires.

These points indicate that *Hollywood Standoff* does not conclusively show that non-agential groups can be non-distributively responsible. Further, there is a case to be made that group responsibility goes hand in hand with individual responsibility in this case, indicating that it is not a case of collective, non-distributive, responsibility after all. It seems that what drives the intuition that the three men are responsible is that they should have cooperated. Each should have taken responsive steps to settle on a joint course of action to lower their guns and give the child their last drops of water, probably via communicating. Each had a duty to collectivize (Collins, 2019; Held, 1970). To the extent this is right, we can argue as follows: If each could take such steps but fails to do so, then clearly, each is (distributively) responsible for this, which would explain why we think they are responsible. However, if they cannot take such steps - each might, for instance, be
PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCHOLOGY

incapable of communicating and too stressed out to understand cues from the others inviting them to lower their guns â then each is excused for not cooperating. However, if none of them could cooperate to save the child, it seems the group is not responsible (distributively or non-distributively) for failing to save the child. This follows from ought implies can. We only get the verdict that the group is responsible but not its members if we think the group could have done something while its members could not. However, I do not see how this situation could arise. If its members cannot do anything about the problem, the group cannot as well.

There is much more to say about Chant's arguments; I do not claim to have done justice to them in this short discussion. If you want to know more, I recommend reading her contribution to the anthology or her other papers on this matter.
Bill Wringe on communicative expressivist theories of punishment

According to communicative expressivism, punishment communicates to the offender that he has acted wrongly. Nozick (1981) develops such an account, drawing heavily on Grice's (1957) account of meaning. According to this account, someone who means by some action to communicate some proposition
p
must intend that some agent:
(i) Comes to believe that
p
(ii) Recognize the intention involved in (i), and
(iii) Have as part of their reason for believing
p
the recognition involved in (ii)

In his contribution to the anthology, Bill Wringe elaborates on an argument against this view he has previously suggested in his (Wringe, 2016) An Expressive Theory of Punishment, showing why it also concerns Duff's (2001) account of punishment.

In essence, Wringe argues that states cannot sincerely communicate to an offender that he has acted wrongly if we understand communication along Gricean lines. The problem lies in (iii). Consider any mala in se crime such as murder or rape. A mature person should think such acts are wrong, not because others have told them so, but because he recognizes the wrongness of such actions. However, Wringe argues, if the state successfully communicates to an offender of such a crime that it is wrong, the offender will not think such acts are wrong merely because he recognizes they are wrong but because the state has told him so: part of his reason for believing that murder and rape are wrong is that he understands that the state wants him to recognize that it intends him to come to believe this.
M.GUNNEMYR

Wringe adds that sometimes, punishment does work like this, for instance, when a parent punishes a young child or when a religious master punishes a novice. In such cases, the punishment communicates to the punished that the punisher intends them to believe that the offense they have committed is wrong (as opposed to just believing that the offense is wrong). The unknowing offender might then take this as indirect evidence for believing that such acts are wrong, giving him a reason to reflect on what he has done and hopefully realize that such actions are wrong. However, for this to work, the punished person must regard the person punishing him as a moral authority. However, Winge continues, offenders of mala in se crimes are unlikely to consider the state a reliable source of morality. It might not even be appropriate for anyone to regard states as reliable sources of morality. Therefore, to successfully communicate to the offender that the kind of act he has committed is wrong, the state must present itself distortedly as a reliable source of morality when it is not. The state must even intend the offender to have this distorted picture of it. And this is problematic, Winge argues.

According to Wringe, the solution is to abandon communicative expressivism in favor of (his version of) denunciatory expressivism. While the former states that punishment communicates something to the offender, the latter says that punishment communicates something to society at large. Wringe adds that it is natural for communicative expressivists to take the content of the message conveyed in punishment to be that the relevant acts are wrong. On Duff's account, for instance, punishment is aimed at remorse and reconciliation, and it is impossible to reach these goals unless the offender recognizes that what he has done is wrong. For denunciatory expressivists, punishment does not have these aims. Therefore, it is open to them to say that the content of the message of punishment is something different, such as that the state is committed to treating such acts as wrong. If we do, we avoid the problem that the state must present itself as a moral authority to communicate the message successfully. It merely must convey what kinds of acts it is committed to treating as wrong.

Bolstering this idea, Wringe draws from Gilbert's (2006) account of joint actions. In her view, the state is a separate agent consisting of its citizens (acting as a body). So, when the state communicates to society as a whole that some act is wrong via punishing offenders, it is really the citizens of the state (acting as a body) communicating to themselves what they are committed to treating as wrong.

Furthermore, communicatory expressivists typically argue that the communicative element of punishment justifies punishment: it is a means to the goal of remorse and reconciliation. This line of reasoning is not open to denunciatory expressivists. However, they
PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCHOLOGY

might instead say that punishment is a natural way for the state to communicate disapproval that the offender has reneged on his commitment to the rules of society. If they would not communicate this, they would not be fully-heartedly committed to treating such offenses as wrong.

Even though there is much to commend in Wringe's paper, one might wonder whether his argument forces a communicative expressivist to abandon the idea that punishment primarily expresses something to the offender. Maybe they could retort by saying that while the state understood as the government is not an appropriate moral authority, the state understood as the embodiment of its citizens might appropriately be thought to be a reliable source of morality. If so, they could avoid Wringe's objection.

If not, they could give up the idea that the punishment is aimed at remorse and reconciliation. Doing so would open for saying that the message punishment conveys is that the state is committed to treating the offense as wrong (rather than that the offense is wrong). Thereby, they would avoid Wringe's objection. Of course, this would be a significant concession from someone like Duff, who thinks punishment is ultimately aimed at remorse and reconciliation. Still, it would not require them to abandon communicative expressivism per se. This concession would, however, force them to abandon the idea that the communicative element of punishment justifies it. Still, they could copy Wringe's idea and say that society communicates disapproval via punishing the offender, albeit adding that it does so primarily to the offender and not society.

Perhaps needless to say, there is more to Wringe's argument than I have been able to say here, and these are just initial pointers as to how a communicative expressivist might answer his arguments. For a deeper discussion, I refer to his paper in the anthology.
Conclusion

As I hope I have made evident, this is an excellent anthology with many exciting contributions to the discussion on collective agency and legal matters. Unfortunately, I have not been able to discuss them all here.
Note
1. The discussion has bearings on the idea that procrastination might be irrational even if no specific action causing a delay is. For a recent contribution to this debate, see e.g., Andreou (2022).
M.GUNNEMYR

M. GUNNEMYR
